hawaiian_text: (Ma ‘ane‘i e ‘ōlelo iki no kēlā mau inoa ‘elua, ‘o  ia ‘o Nāmakaokalani a me Nāmakaokai‘a, he mau  ali‘i nui lāua no Hawai‘i, he makua kāne ‘o  Nāmakaokalani a he keiki ‘o Nāmakaokai‘a, akā, ua  komo i loko o ka pule a Nāmakaokapāo‘o.)
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Now let's talk briefly about those two names, Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai'a, they were both high chiefs of Hawai'i, Nāmakaokalani was the father and Nāmakaokai'a was the child, but they were included in the prayers of Nāmakaokapāo'o.

• The paragraph begins by mentioning two new names: Nā-maka-o-ka-lani and Nā-maka-o-kai-'a. These names are likely related to the main protagonist, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, and may hold significance in understanding his character and role in the story.
– The name Nā-maka-o-ka-lani can be broken down into its constituent parts: Nā- (the) + maka (eyes) + o (of) + ka (the) + lani (sky or heaven). This name may suggest a connection to the spiritual or heavenly realm.
– The name Nā-maka-o-kai-'a can be similarly broken down: Nā- (the) + maka (eyes) + o (of) + ka (the) + i (sea or ocean) + 'a (a particle indicating a nominalizing function). This name may indicate a connection to the ocean or the physical world.
• The relationship between Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai'a is described as father and child, respectively. This may imply a generational or hierarchical connection between the two characters.
– In Hawaiian culture, the concept of ohana (family) is deeply important, and the relationships between generations are often seen as crucial to understanding an individual's identity and role in society.
• The fact that Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai'a are included in the prayers of Nāmakaokapāo'o suggests that they may hold spiritual or cultural significance in the story.
– In the 'Ai Kapu era, prayer and spiritual practices were an integral part of daily life, and the inclusion of specific individuals in prayers may have been seen as a way of honoring or seeking guidance from those individuals.
• The mention of these two characters and their relationship to Nāmakaokapāo'o may also serve to highlight the themes of identity, community, and cultural heritage that are present throughout the story.
– The use of names with similar etymologies (Nā-maka-o-) may indicate a sense of continuity or connection between the characters, and may serve to emphasize the importance of understanding one's roots and heritage in navigating the challenges of life.

reference_translation: (Here, I’ll talk a little about those two names,  Nāmakaokalani and Nāmakaokai‘a, which are  names of high chiefs of Hawai‘i. Nāmakaokalani  was the father and Nāmakaokai‘a was the son, but  these names were mentioned in the prayer of  Nāmakaokapāo‘o.)
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
